title: Derivations for Frequnecy Domain FEV
text: Assume VAR(p) process following form: \[ (L) X_t = \upsilon_t \] \(X_t\) \(N \times 1\) vector data \((L)\) matrix polynomial lag operator, \(L\) \(\upsilon_t\) vector residuals, .e. reduced-form shocks \(p\) represents number lags data included VAR \(E[\upsilon_t \upsilon_t'] = \Sigma\), \(\Sigma\) variance-covariance matrix residuals lag matrix following structure: \[ (L) \equiv \sum_{T=0}^{p} A_T L^T \\ (0) = A_0 = \]

title: Derivations for Frequnecy Domain FEV
text: Assume linear mapping, \(S\), \(v_t\) independent structural shocks, \(\epsilon_t\). \[ \upsilon_t = S \epsilon_t \] \(E[\epsilon_t \epsilon_t'] = \). convenient represent \(S\) rotation Choleskey decomposition, \(\tilde{S}\), \(\Sigma\). \[ S = \tilde{S}Q \] \(Q\) orthonormal matrix (\(Q^{-1} = Q'\)) represents rotation. infinitely many possible rotations \(Q\) satisfy linear mapping. Taking \(Q = \) uses Choleskey decomposition identification relies upon ordering variables. Sign restriction identification involes drawing many possible matrices \(Q\) keeping set required signs impact. Angeletos, Collard, Dellas (2020) paper package instead identify \(Q\) matrix leads one structural shock explaining largest portion forecast error variance targetted variable, either time frequency domain.

title: Derivations for Frequnecy Domain FEV
text: moving average representation VAR given \[ X_t = B(L) \upsilon_t \] \(B(L) = (L)^{-1} = \sum_{T=0}^{\infty}B_TL^T\) infinite matrix polynomial. , easy rewrite model \[ X_t = C(L) Q \epsilon_t = \Gamma(L) \epsilon_t \] \(C(L) = = \sum_{T=0}^{\infty}C_TL^T\) \(C_T \equiv B_T \tilde{S}\) \(\Gamma(L) = = \sum_{T=0}^{\infty}\Gamma_TL^T\) \(\Gamma_T \equiv B_T \tilde{S} Q\).

title: Derivations for Frequnecy Domain FEV
text: Hamilton, James D. Time Series Analsysis. Chapter 6: Spectral Analysis. Pg 152 - 172. particular, page 154 deriving population spectrum MA(infinity) process. Kilian, Lutz Lutekepohl Helmut. Structural Vector Autoregressive Analysis. Chapter 2: Vector Autoregressive Models. Pg 19 - . particular, page 25 representing VAR(p) process VAR(1) process. Angeletos, George-Marios, Fabrice Collard, Harris Dellas. (2020). “Businsess Cycle Anatomy”. American Economic Review, 110(10): 3030 - 3070. particular, pages 3036 - 3037 derivations.

what: Main Shock Forecast Error Variance Identification
title: Main Shock Forecast Error Variance Identification
text: R package identify structural VAR shocks using maximization explained forecast error variances. Implemented target either time domain frequency domain.

title: Main Shock Forecast Error Variance Identification
text: can install development version fevdid GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("VFCI/fevdid")

what: Main Shock in the Time Domain
title: Main Shock Forecast Error Variance Identification
text: Example identifying main shock along time domain. target variable inflation four ten quarters . figure compares identified main shock Choleskey shock inflation, already explains variation simple 3-variable VAR. Clearly, however, contribution Main shock higher targeted time period.  Getting impulse responses identified main shock VARs handled usual irf function.  Plotting forecast variance decompositions equally straightforward (code used compare two separate fevds).
code: require(fevdid)  ## US data on inflation (pi), output (x), and federal funds rate (i) x <- svars::USA v <- vars::VAR(x, p = 2) sv <- svars::id.chol(v, order_k = c("x", "pi", "i"))  ## Find shock that maximizes forecast error variance for inflation (pi) ## from 4 to 10 quarters out mv <- id_fevdtd(v, target = "pi", horizon = 4:10)  ## Comparing fevds fevdsv <- vars::fevd(sv, n.ahead = 20)$pi fevdmv <- vars::fevd(mv, n.ahead = 20)$pi   ## Plotting require(ggplot2) cbind(h = 1:20, fevdsv, fevdmv) |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = !h) |>   dplyr::filter(name %in% c("Main", "pi")) |>   ggplot(aes(x = h, y = value, color = name)) +   geom_vline(xintercept = c(4, 10)) +   geom_line() irfsv <- vars::irf(sv) irfmv <- vars::irf(mv)  cowplot::plot_grid(plot(irfsv), plot(irfmv), nrow = 1) fevdsv <- vars::fevd(sv, n.ahead = 20) fevdmv <- vars::fevd(mv, n.ahead = 20)  cowplot::plot_grid(plot(fevdsv), plot(fevdmv), nrow = 1)

what: Main Shock in the Frequency Domain
title: Main Shock Forecast Error Variance Identification
text: Example identifying main shock along frequency domain. target variable inflation $\frac{2\pi}{32}$ $\frac{2\pi}{6}$, “business cycle” frequencies. figure compares identified main shock Choleskey shock inflation, already explains variation simple 3-variable VAR. contribution Main shock higher targeted frequency period.  also generic plot function frequency domain fevds.
code: require(fevdid)  ## US data on inflation (pi), output (x), and federal funds rate (i) x <- svars::USA v <- vars::VAR(x, p = 2) sv <- svars::id.chol(v, order_k = c("x", "pi", "i"))  ## Find shock that maximizes forecast error variance for inflation (pi) ## in the "business cycle" frequencies bc_freqs <- c(2 * pi / 32, 2 * pi / 6) mfv <- id_fevdfd(v, target = "pi", freqs = bc_freqs)  ## Comparing fevds fevdsv <- fevdfd(sv)$pi fevdmv <- fevdfd(mfv)$pi  ## Plotting require(ggplot2) dplyr::full_join(fevdsv, fevdmv, by = "f") |>   dplyr::as_tibble() |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = !f) |>   dplyr::filter(name %in% c("Main", "pi")) |>   ggplot(aes(x = f, y = value, color = name)) +   geom_vline(xintercept = bc_freqs) +   geom_line() fevdsv <- fevdfd(sv) fevdmv <- fevdfd(mv)  cowplot::plot_grid(plot(fevdsv), plot(fevdmv), nrow = 1)

title: Main Shock Forecast Error Variance Identification
text: Chapter 6: “Forecast error variance maximization” book Identification Dynamic Stuctural Shocks, Jean-Paul Renne Kenza Benhima. jrenne Github Explains codes example identifying shock maximizes forecast error variance contribution. “moves real GNP?”. Harlad Uhlig. (2003).

title: Calculate the forecast error variance in the frequency domain. — fevdfd
code: fevdfd(var, ...)  # S3 method for svars fevdfd(var, freqs = c(0, 2 * pi), grid_size = 1000, fev = FALSE, ...)  # S3 method for fevdvar fevdfd(var, freqs = c(0, 2 * pi), grid_size = 1000, fev = FALSE, ...)

title: Calculate the forecast error variance in the frequency domain. — fevdfd
text: var VAR. Currently supports either 'svars' 'fevdvar' object. ... Used pass arguments fevdfd.svars fevdfd.fevdvar. freqs vector length 2 min max frequencies (0:2pi) grid_size fine grid approximate frequency domain fev Boolean true return fev fevd

title: Calculate the forecast error variance in the frequency domain. — fevdfd
text: List forecast error variance decomposition frequency domain List variables, dataframe shocks, column 'f' frequencies.

title: Calculate the forecast error variance in the frequency domain. — fevdfd
code: x <- svars::USA v <- vars::VAR(x, p = 2) sv <- svars::id.chol(v) fevd <- fevdfd(sv)
